newsitem.title: BELGIUM: American Airlines to cut Brussels-NY JFK route.
newsitem.headline: American Airlines to cut Brussels-NY JFK route.

text.p: American Airlines said on Wednesday it was being forced by unfair competition to end its daily flight from Brussels to New York's JFK airport with effect from October 1 after losing money consistently.
However, the airline's profitable regular service from the Belgian capital to its hub in Chicago will remain in operation, sales manager Olga Jacob said by telephone.

She said a three-way alliance between Sabena, Delta and Swissair -- which has hubs in Brussels and New York -- had the benefit of anti-trust immunity, while American Airlines' planned alliance with British Airways remained blocked.
"Sabena-Delta put on a second daily Brussels-New York flight about a year ago. It is running with excess capacity and cutting prices," she said.
"Since they put on that extra flight, we have consistently lost money on the New York route."
As there is no "open skies" agreement between Britain and the United States, the British Airways alliance could not proceed, she said.
"We are being blocked while our European competitors have anti-trust immunity and can set prices and take market share," she commented.
Hans Mirka, American Airlines' senior international vice president, said in a statement the decision to end the daily Brussels to New York flight, in operation since 1989, was sad but necessary.
He, too, complained that the airline faced an uneven playing field in Europe.
"It is very difficult to compete effectively in a market such as Brussels where the rules are substantially different for our competitors," he added.
